description: From Middle French detester, from Latin detestari (“to imprecate evil while calling the gods to witness", "denounce", "hate intensely”), from de- + testari (“to testify, bear witness”), from testis (“a witness”); see test, testify.

verbs.description: detest (third-person singular simple present detests, present participle detesting, simple past and past participle detested)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To dislike (someone or something) intensely; to loathe.
(transitive, obsolete) To witness against; to denounce; to condemn.
examples: The heresy of Nestorius  […]  was detested in the Eastern churches.
